title: East Coweta finishes perfect season with CCMSAL title
text:
East Coweta finishes perfect season with CCMSAL title by Brian Chmielewski, Special to the Times-Herald Wednesday, October 21, 2015 Comments 
The Indians celebrate after head coach Chase Smith was given a victorious water jug bath after wrapping up a 25-12 victory to win this year’s CCMSAL Championship. 
East Coweta capped off a perfect season to win this year’s Coweta County Middle School Athletic League football championship on Tuesday by holding off second-seeded Madras 25-12 at Garland Shoemake Stadium. 
The Indians, coached by Chase Smith, battled back from a 6-0 deficit to hand Madras both of its two losses during the 2015 season. Christopher Moore rushed for 122 yards and two touchdowns on 14 carries to help finish a 7-0 season. 
The Eagles, which advanced to the championship game with last week’s semifinal win over Lee, used a defensive stop on a fake punt to set up their opening score. 
Two plays after taking over on its own 42-yard line, Madras got on the scoreboard with a 40-yard strike from Jake Barberio to Mason Bervaldi with 3:02 left in the first quarter. 
East Coweta stormed right back, however, needing two plays to go ahead for good. 
Corey Bridges connected with Jayland Rivers on a 72-yard pass play to push East ?Coweta a ahead 7-6 with 1:34 left in the first quarter. 
Neither team managed to score in the second quarter, but East Coweta easily could have pulled away. 
The Indians had two long runs by Christopher Moore called back for penalties two plays apart. As a result the game went to the half with the Indians still leading 7-6. 
East Coweta successfully pulled away to open the second half, scoring on consecutive drives. 
Moore went in from 31-yards out with 6:27 to go in the quarter and made it 13-6 after a missed PAT. After the Eagles ran one play the Indians Austin Bunn intercepted Barberio to set his offense up at the Eagles' 27-yard line. Two plays later Moore scored again, from 25-yards out to extend the lead to 19-6 with 5:13 to go in the third quarter. 
Early in the fourth quarter Madras recovered a fumble that gave the Eagles the ball near midfield. Three plays later Barberio broke several tackles to score from 10-yards away and cut the Indians’ lead to 19-12 with 6:47 left in the game. 
East Coweta answered on the ensuing drive going down the field in five plays capped off by a 16-yard run by Marshay Walker to make it 25-12 with 4:47 to go. 
Madras drove to near midfield on their last posses- sion of the game, but failed to convert a fourth-and-long allowing East Coweta to take over at the 38-yard line of the Eagles where they managed run out the clock.
